review: Almost at an impulse-buy price point, these things offer a remarkable value for $35. Sharing a TV for crowd sourcing youtube videos among friends, turning your TV into a big screen projector for your laptop, controlling Netflix from your computer while being free to use it for other purposes ... it's just amazing. Set-up is a cinch. If your TV lacks a USB port to power it then you use the included power cord so installation is always a success if you've got a spare HDMI port. Network configuration is easy if you are accessing wifi directly. The only down side isn't the device's fault ... when there's an interstitial web site for setting up wifi (as in a hotel room) then the device can't gain access. It's so small that I carry one with me with I travel. Why do I have five? Because I think they're so cool that I've purchased three and given them away. Highly recommended.
author: Travis Good "Travis Good"

review: We bought the Chromecast when it was first released, and have since bought several others as gifts for friends and family. This is the most user friendly and cost effective way to stream Netflix and HBO Go to your tv, with the added bonus that you can broadcast anything from the Chrome browser on your computer. Our household already had this functionality, but the Chromecast simplified the process with a much smaller product. Highly recommend!

review: Got this as a gift for the holidays - it was a somewhat rocky install on both my iphone and chromebook. The unit had to do updates which took some time. After setup, it becomes clear what this does and what it DOES NOT do. If you want to watch home videos to your tv, that (at least right now) isn't doable unless you have the files stored online and have the right app and settings to cast them. I wanted to show my family some videos I had on my iphone and wasn't able to do so. I converted the videos and uploaded them to Google docs and they still wouldn't play right (fuzzy and/or no sound). This item can easily be replaced by a plethora of current/older tech that (IMO) works far better - hopefully Google will get Amazon (hint hint) to add the ability to stream videos and add more apps/providers. This item is also 100% dependant on your wireless speeds - high res video will stutter or get blocky over time.
